Soit $f : {[0,+\infty[} \to \R$ continue telle que $ \int_{t=0}^{+\infty} f(t)\,d t$
converge. Montrer que $\frac1x \int_{t=0}^x tf(t)\,d t \to 0$ lorsque $x\to+\infty$.
value.html: Soit \(f : {[0,+\infty[} \to \R\) continue telle que \(\int_{t=0}^{+\infty} f(t)\,d t\) converge. Montrer que \(\frac1x \int_{t=0}^x tf(t)\,d t \to 0\) lorsque \(x\to+\infty\).

value.latex:
Soit $F(x) =  \int_{t=0}^x f(t)\,d t$ :
         $\frac1x \int_{t=0}^x tf(t)\,d t = F(x) - \frac1x \int_{t=0}^x F(t)\,d t$.
value.html: Soit \(F(x) = \int_{t=0}^x f(t)\,d t\) : \(\frac1x \int_{t=0}^x tf(t)\,d t = F(x) - \frac1x \int_{t=0}^x F(t)\,d t\).
